titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the August Jaccaci Papers, 1889-1935 (bulk 1904-1914), in the Archives of American Art
titlestmt.author: by Erin Corley
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing and digitization of this collection was provided by the Terra Foundation for American Art.

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Erin Corley on June 02, 2006

did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

did.abstract: The papers of art historican August Jaccaci measure 7.2 linear feet and date from 1889 to 1935, with the bulk of the material dating from 1904 to 1914. The collection documents Jaccaci's work as an art historian, writer, and editor, primarily during the period he researched, compiled, and published his book Noteworthy Paintings in Private American Collections. More than one-half of the collection consists of extensive correspondence to and from many notable artists, collectors, and art historians, including John La Farge, Kenyon Cox, Isabella Stewart Gardner, and Bernard Sickert concerning the research and publication of the book. The papers also house legal files, writings and notes, art collection research files, and photographs of artwork.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: August Florian Jaccaci was born in Fontainebleau, France in 1856. After traveling extensively in various countries including Mexico and Cuba, he settled in the United States in the early 1880s. He worked briefly as an artist in the Midwest, creating murals on commission, including a mural in the Capitol building in St. Paul, Minnesota. Jaccaci then moved to New York City and worked as art editor for Century magazine. Besides serving as art editor, he also wrote several articles and executed illustrations for the magazine. On the recommendation of artist Will H. Low he became art editor of McClure's magazine at its founding in 1896. A year later he wrote the book on his travels entitled, On the trail of Don Quixote: being a record of rambles in the ancient province of La Mancha [sic]. He left McClure's in 1902 and in 1903 began working on a major multi-volume book entitled Noteworthy Paintings in Private American Collections. Jaccaci envisioned a 15 volume set with essays about American art collections written by distinguished art historians. Though Jaccaci knew many writers, art critics, and artists through his magazine work, he was not a well-known art historian and asked artist John La Farge to be the co-editor of the book. La Farge's reputation provided access to major American collections of artwork. The publishing company Merrill and Baker was to publish the work, but it went bankrupt in 1904. Jaccaci then bought their property for his project and called it the August F. Jaccaci Co. The first volume was published in 1909, and John La Farge died in 1910. Though Jaccaci continued working on the next volume, the project failed in 1912. Besides working on this project, Jaccaci also served as editor of the "Art in America" section of Burlington Magazine from 1907 to 1910.

In 1914 August Jaccaci went to Europe on art related business. With the start of World War I, he decided to stay in France and pursue philanthropic work. He founded the Society for Protection of Children of the Frontier, and established a children's hospital, receiving many honors for his service. He died in Neuf-De-Grasse, France in 1930.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of art historican August Jaccaci measure 7.2 linear feet and date from 1889 to 1935, with the bulk of the material dating from 1904 to 1914. The collection documents Jaccaci's work as an art historian, writer, and editor, primarily during the period he researched, compiled, and published his book Noteworthy Paintings in Private American Collections. More than one-half of the collection consists of extensive correspondence to and from many notable artists, collectors, and art historians, including John La Farge, Kenyon Cox, Isabella Stewart Gardner, and Bernard Sickert concerning the research and publication of the book. The papers also house legal files, writings and notes, art collection research files, and photographs of artwork.

Correspondents include art historians, critic, artists, and art collectors, as well as publishers, photographers, printers, and agents. These letters discuss the research of famous American art collections, writing of essays for the book, and the book production and publication. There is extensive correspondence with his co-editor John La Farge, and with his employee Carl Snyder who was working in Europe. Other correspondence is with magazines, art associations, academic institutions, and French service organizations. Also included is a small amount of personal correspondence with friends and colleagues.

Legal files include contracts and legal agreements for the August F. Jaccaci Company, as well as legal agreements with John La Farge concerning the research and publication of their joint book. Writings and notes include Jaccaci's lists and notes pertaining to the Noteworthy Paintings project, as well as other miscellaneous notes. Also found are writings by John La Farge that include drafts of a book, lectures, and notes about his artwork. Writings by others in this series also include draft essays by many art historians for Jaccaci's book. For the Noteworthy Paintings project, Jaccaci created numerous research files for American art collections and collectors that would be included. These research files include lists of works of art, essays and other notes about the collection written by prominent art historians. Photographs are of works of art supporting the research files. Also found in this collection are photographs of and notes about New England stencil designs. It is unclear what the connection is between Jaccaci and the stencil designs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into 5 series:

list.item: Series 3: Writings and Notes, 1903-1914, undated (Box 5; 0.6 linear feet)
Series 4: Art Collection Research Files, 1889, 1892, 1903-1914, undated (Box 5-7; 2.0 linear feet)

arrangement.p: Due to re-processing, the order of the collection varies slightly from the order of the collection on microfilm. References to the microfilm reel numbers have been added for researcher access.

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed in the online catalog of the Archives of American Art under the following index terms. People, families and organizations are listed under "Subjects" when they are the topic of collection contents and under "Names" when they are creators or contributors.

controlaccess.head: Subjects-Topical:
controlaccess.subject: Art historians -- New York (State) -- New York
Art -- Collectors and collecting

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The August Jaccaci papers were purchased by the Archives of American Art from the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1957 and microfilmed shortly after receipt.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research. Patrons must use microfilm copy. Use of materials not available on microfilm requires an appointment.

userestrict.head: Ownership and Literary Rights
userestrict.p: The August Jaccaci papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

altformavail.head: Alternative Forms Available
altformavail.p: The collection is available on 35 mm microfilm reels D118-D126 at Archives of American Art offices, and through interlibrary loan. Researchers should note that the order of the papers as re-processed varies from the order of collection on microfilm.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: August Jaccaci papers, 1889-1935. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed shortly after purchase and microfilmed on reels D118-D126. Photographs of artwork were not microfilmed. Previously microfilmed and unmicrofilmed portions were arranged, and described in accordance with archival standards by Erin Corley in 2006 as part of the Terra Foundation for American Art Digitization Grant. The order of the papers is slightly different than the order of the microfilmed papers. References to the reel numbers have been added to the finding aid.

scopecontent.p: More than one-half of the collection consists of Jaccaci's correspondence with everyone connected with the publication of his book Noteworthy Paintings in Private American Collections. The bulk of the correspondence dates from 1903 to 1913 and is between Jaccaci and the art historians, curators, critics, and art collectors concerning the compilation of the numerous essays for the book. Correspondents include Wilhelm Bode, Kenyon Cox, Lionel Cust, William H. Downes, Max Friedlander, Roger Fry, Isabella Stewart Gardner, Jules Guiffrey, Lewis Hind, C. J. Holmes, Paul LaFond, Frank Jewett Mather, Jr., Ernst Moes, Bernhard Sickert, Oswald Siren, Mariana G. Van Rensselaer, and others. Jaccaci also corresponded with artists such as Aureliano de Beruete, Mary Cassatt, Ben Foster, Will H. Low, Harper Pennington, Rudolph Ruzicka, and Augustus Tack.

Also included is a large amount of correspondence between John La Farge (co-editor of the book)and Jaccaci. Additional La Farge correspondence is found throughout this series as he also corresponded with many people and organizations about the book. Researchers should note some of the correspondence is signed and addressed to La Farge's secretary Grace E. Barnes. There is also a large amount of correspondence in this series with Carl Snyder, an agent working for Jaccaci in Europe. Also found is Jaccaci's correspondence with photographers, such as Frederick O. Bemm, as well as publishers, art associations, and academic institutions. Also included is a small amount of correspondence with American Magazine, Burlington Magazine, and McClure's, concerning his work as an editor.

Scattered correspondence between Jaccaci and his friends, former co-workers, and his son August Thayer Jaccaci is found in this series. Other correspondence concerns printing and publishing, his work with French services organizations during World War One, and legal and investment matters.

Correspondence is arranged alphabetically by name of the correspondent, or, in a few instances, by topic. Unidentified letters have been arranged at the end of the series. For folders containing letters from more than one correspondent, the individual names are listed underneath the folder heading. Miscellaneous correspondence is listed after the alphabetical correspondence.

scopecontent.p: Legal files include a mortgage contract for the August F. Jaccaci Company as well as Jaccaci legal agreements related to his company and the rights for his book Noteworthy Paintings. Also found are legal agreements made by John La Farge concerning his artwork and publication rights in the book. This series also contains court documents concerning the theft of prints and negatives of artwork.

did.unittitle: August F. Jaccaci Company Mortgage Contract, 1906
John La Farge Legal Agreements, 1895, 1897, undated
Court Documents, William A. Cooper v. William G. Gray, circa 1905

scopecontent.p: This series contains writings and notes by August Jaccaci, John La Farge, and others. Included are Jaccaci's lists of works of art, photographs, essays, and payments for his Noteworthy Paintings project. Also included are Jaccaci's notes on his research of Martin, King of Aragon & Sicily, and other miscellaneous notes.

Writings by John La Farge include notes and a complete typescript of his book One Hundred Masterpieces of Painting, published posthumously in 1912. Included are notes written by others about the publication of the work. Also found are notes and drafts for a series of lectures La Farge gave on the Barbizon School of France at the Art Institute of Chicago known as the Scammon lectures, and miscellaneous notes about his artwork.

Writings by others include draft essays written by various art historians and critics such as Arsène Alexandre and Gabriel Mourey for Jaccaci's book Noteworthy Paintings. Many of the essays have handwritten annotations. Also found in this series are sample page proofs from Gillis Press, the proposed printer of the book, as well as vouchers of payment to the writers of the essays for the book. Researchers should note that writings about artwork from American art collections are also found in Series 4: Art Collection Research Files.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of research files about American art collections and individual works of art that were to be featured in August Jaccaci's book Noteworthy Paintings in Private American Collections. Collections and collectors covered include Isabella Stewart Gardner, J. Pierpont Morgan, Henry Clay Frick, John Hay, William H. Vanderbilt, Peter A. B. Widener, and others. Arranged alphabetically by collector name, the files contain a variety of research materials that often include manuscript and typescript essays about the collection and individual works of art, notes, and scattered photographs. Most of the photographs of artwork from these art collections can be found in Series 5.2: Photographs of artwork. Essays were written by prominent art historians and artists, including Kenyon Cox, Harper Pennington, Samuel Isham, Max Friedlander, Ernst Moes, as well as many others.

did.unittitle: Sir William Van Horne Collection, 1913, undated
Peter A. B. Widener Collection, 1905-1914, undated

arrangement.p: The Photographs series is arranged into 2 subseries:

scopecontent.p: Photographs of stencils includes a folder with an essay and notes about stencils, a folder with photographs of stenciling tools and folders containing photographs of stencil designs and photographs of stenciled walls and floors from historic homes, primarily in the New England region.

scopecontent.p: Photographs of Artwork include black and white photographs of famous paintings found in some of the collections listed in Series 4: Art Collection Research Files. Some of the photographs are labeled and attributed to certain collections, though some are not labeled.
